repnme.cdata!:
Indonesia - Integrated Pest Management
            Training Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project had a mixed record in
            achieving its project objectives, but a critical mass of
            pest observers and farmer trainers have been educated in
            integrated pest management (IPM) concepts and methods, have
            better training skills, and are now prepared to train
            farmers and promote IPM practices in their communities. The
            technical base for IPM has been enhanced by field studies
            carried out by the farmers themselves. Government actions
            have created a policy environment more conducive to adopting
            IPM concepts and practices. A key institutional
            strengthening outcome was the increased motivation and
            ability of farmers to organize themselves into local groups
            and national associations. These gains make the project
            outcome satisfactory, but only marginally so because the
            project could have achieved much more. That so much was
            achieved is due chiefly to the soundness of the IPM concepts
            applied, the enthusiasm of field leaders, and the strong
            field-level support by the FAO technical assistance team.
            Overall World Bank and Borrower performances are rated
            satisfactory. Project sustainability is likely. The full
            impact of the project was not achieved because of quality at
            entry and implementation problems discussed here:
            Organizational arrangements needed to be clearly defined and
            adjusted before, not during, project preparation. The
            unavailability of good baseline data and the late and
            ineffective development of an monitoring and evaluation
            system limited the impact evaluation study.

repnme.cdata!:
Indonesia - Integrated Pest Management
            Training Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project will inter alia support:
            (a) human resource development to promote a bottom-up
            concept of extension services and farmer-participatory
            approach for implementing the integrated pest management
            (IPM) program (about 520 pest observers, 1,100 extension
            workers and 800,000 farmers will be trained, with about 30
            percent of trainees being women); (b) supporting studies and
            field investigations (i) to develop appropriate
            farmer-responsive technology, including a program of
            investigation into pest/natural enemy interactions in
            different eco-systems; (ii) an occupational health study,
            and (iii) contracted out research to local universities; and
            (c) strengthening the regulatory and environmental
            management of pesticides. This will include a review and
            strengthening of the effectiveness of the pesticides
            commission, review and phase-out of the most hazardous
            pesticides, collation/dissemination of information and
            improvements in labelling, packaging, storage, as well as
            undertaking the environmental audits of
            manufacturing/formulation plants.
